questions.neutral: Is the city acting weird lately?

hobby.message: Origami help keep the noise out?
Antique typewriters and quiet bars — good pair.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: City feels off. Too tense for comfort lately.
I do origami. Used to calm my nerves.
Crowds outside keep ruining the quiet.
Hard to focus with street noise always lurking.
Yeah, the atmosphere’s strange. Everything’s unsettled.
I fold origami at home. It’s gotten tougher.
Last night, protests made my hands tremble.
Even making a simple crane felt risky.
Noise seeps in. Can’t fold without interruptions.
Things are unnerving, that’s true. Streets feel on edge.
I do complex origami—mostly modular, sometimes roses.
It used to help me relax after work.
Now I can’t get through a model without sirens cutting in.
Feels like every night, assemblies outside disrupt my folds.
Even the paper—kept using old flyers from protest groups.
Feels like the city’s unraveling at the seams lately.
I’ve always folded origami, especially intricate modular pieces. It’s a bit obsessive.
After shifts, I’d make roses from recycled city notices. Used to be soothing.
Recently, assemblies and noise spill over—my walls rattle, and so do my hands.
The last street court was audible from my kitchen. Folds went sharp with nerves.
Messed up a kusudama sphere for the first time in years.
Never realized how much I counted on silence for precision.
Honestly, the tension is everywhere—I can barely hear myself think some nights.
You know, folding origami kept my anxiety in check for years. Not children’s stuff; I work on things like Kawasaki roses, sonobe cubes.
With the city obsessed over assemblies and justice, it’s changed. I use whatever scrap I find—sometimes flyers about street courts, sometimes eviction notices.
Once, those models felt like secret protest—turning surveillance leftovers into something precise, controlled.
But last week, the protests outside shook my hands so badly I misfolded a whole set.
Origami’s all math and muscle memory. Now every siren or neighbor’s knock throws me off.
Even the patterns I find comforting, like hydrangea folds, feel twisted now.
I miss when quiet meant safety; now, too much depends on sound carrying through walls.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Keeps my hands steady. Helps ignore the noise outside.
Not much to say. Just paper, folds, repetition.
Assemblies on my block now—hard to focus.
I don't make anything complicated these days. Too risky.
People look at you sideways if you’re seen making things.
It helps. Sometimes. Not lately, though.
Harder with assemblies holding court outside my window.
Paper's scarce. I use whatever I can scavenge.
Used to finish roses in ten minutes, now I rush or hide them.
They say it’s just a hobby, but lately, people judge everything.
Hard to know who’s watching, who’ll talk.
Yeah, origami helps most days, but last week—I couldn’t focus.
Street courts held hearings in my building. The noise rattled my hands.
I ruined two foxes and a rose. Never used to happen.
Anything too careful or pretty makes people stare now.
Even kids in the stairwell ask who you’re making things for.
I stick to plain models, and keep the paper scraps hidden.
Nobody trusts quiet pastimes—feels like everyone’s watching, all the time.
It does mostly, but lately not so much. Assemblies keep disrupting routines.
Last Sunday, I tried folding a tessellation, but protests blared up outside.
I used to measure every crease precisely. Now I work from scraps, quick and sloppy.
Sometimes neighbors ask if I’m wasting paper or sending signals. Paranoia’s everywhere.
I miss when origami was just mine—no one judged what I made.
Even friends from Oversight whisper if I bring a model to work.
Guess hobbies look suspicious now, like everything else.
Still, folding keeps my thoughts from spiraling, even if the roses look rough.
Yeah, origami helps stop the spiraling, but these days... not as much.
Used to fold after work—cranes, tessellations, polyhedra. It was quiet, private.
After the street courts started, my hands shake when the crowd chants.
Sometimes I crumple the whole thing if I hear protests close by.
My last lotus was ruined—sweat and noise, and a knock at my door half-finished it.
I even catch myself hiding finished models. Feels safer.
When my BCI hit zero, neighbors started asking why I still bother with paper.
I keep folding, but I watch the window now. Can’t help it.
Origami was my way out—now it's chained to the city’s mood, like everything else.
